qas.question: What group of the periodic table is copper in?
Name a property that copper, silver and gold have in common.
What makes copper bondings weaker than other metals?
What is a weaker form of copper than fine-grained polycrystalline?
What group of the periodic table is copper no longer in?
What is the only property that copper, silver and gold have in common?
What makes copper bondings stronger than other metals?
What is a better form of copper than fine-grained polycrystalline?

context: Copper, silver and gold are in <a0_0><b5_0>group 11<b5_0/><a0_0/> of the periodic table, and they share certain attributes: they have <a1_0><b6_0>one s-orbital electron<b6_0/><a1_0/> on top of a <a2_0><b7_0>filled d-electron shell<b7_0/><a2_0/> and are characterized by high ductility and electrical conductivity. The filled d-shells in these elements do not contribute much to the interatomic interactions, which are dominated by the s-electrons through metallic bonds. Unlike metals with incomplete d-shells, metallic bonds in copper are lacking a covalent character and are relatively weak. This explains the low hardness and high ductility of single crystals of copper. At the macroscopic scale, introduction of extended defects to the crystal lattice, such as grain boundaries, hinders flow of the material under applied stress, thereby increasing its hardness. For this reason, copper is usually supplied in a <a3_0><b8_0>fine-grained polycrystalline form<b8_0/><a3_0/>, which has greater strength than <a4_0><b9_0>monocrystalline forms<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
